text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then in about one-third of patients, the cancer neither grows nor shrinks. So it basically stabilizes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And that stabilization typically lasts anywhere from six to twelve months. So it’s not permanent. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: It’s just for a period of time. And then the last third, the cancer continued to grow at roughly the same pace that it was growing before. Patient: How so? Doctor: So the therapy did not appear to be effective. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay.

Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay.

text: Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: So what usually happens in general for clinical trials is that if you're interested in clinical trials, what I'll do is I'll contact the research nurse, and I'll say, you know, “Mr. H____ is interested in this clinical trial let's do it” because we have to make sure that your insurance allows you to be in clinical trials, and we have to confirm your eligibility and like for this, the MAP study- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Patient: Did you get the results I emailed you. The DNA. Doctor: Yes. So, I got back the germline genetics testing. So this that this testing, well, do you remember? Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this.

Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this.

text: Family Member: Not the sixteenth? Doctor: I’ll e-mail him, but you can also tell him at the next appointment. Patient: I will. Doctor: You think it’s best – does he think it’s a good idea? He and I do this all the time. We, we transition after he’s finished with the radiation part. Because, unless - I mean, he’s not going away. We might need him again. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Down the road maybe. I don’t know. I hope not. But, but, but I think in terms of talking about the next trials, all those kinds of things, you need to be with, you’re going to, that’s going to be me. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: I have a question. text: Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo? Doctor: No, we would stop it. Family Member: Okay, then I was gonna say I kind of misinterpreted that. Doctor: Yeah, we just stop the Xtandi. Patient: Continue it until I start the trial? Doctor: Nope, you just stop it. It's not doing its thing. If you want to do the trial, or if you're okay with chemo as the next step. But either way Xtandi’s not doing it. So we need to bail out of that. It's just giving you side effects with no gain. Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment Doctor: I think there's like a good at least two to three week washout you know we got to let that one get out of your system. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: -and then start the new thing. Family Member: Oh I didn’t realize that. Doctor: Otherwise you can get drug interaction- Family Member: Okay.

The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And we would keep you on it if we’re going to do the immuno-therapy study. We would stop it if we were going to go to chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles. Doctor: So, right. So, we start the hormones. We get you chemotherapy. We give you a little bit of a break. I don’t know if it’s a month- Healthcare Professional: Mm Hmm. Doctor: And then you have your surgery. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then, based on what we see under the microscope, they can discern whether or not we’re gonna give you radiation to your prostate to try to clean up the area or is it all pretty decent. And, then they can plan the spot radiation to the sites that we’ve seen before. (pause) Patient: Yeah, it was a lymph node and Doctor: Right. So, they’ll be more pictures at that point. Sometimes when we use the hormones and the chemo, uh, things start to heal. Things that we can’t see now with our pictures. And, then, things pop up. Uh. And that’s just because they’re healing, so we can now see them. Uh. But your PSA is zero and you feel well with taking your prostate out, so that would then give them information as to sort of, okay this is what we can offer at that point. Patient: Okay. What’s the downside? Doctor: Umm. Downside? More therapy than you should be getting. Patient: Okay. Doctor: A lot of therapy in a young guy. So, we think you’re the right guy to get it because you can probably handle it all. Uh, but T_ and I, when we’ve been working together this last week, uh - There’s a lot of safety built in that, you know, instead of going six cycles, we could stop after four cycles. You know, some of these sorts of just tweaking things to make sure we don’t, uh, you know, go too far. And, that’s some of the reason why we see you every three weeks when you’re on the chemo. Uh. ‘Cuz we wanna make sure we’re not going too far. Uh. And, you know, the whole concept of doing this together, there is nothing about this that we haven’t done before, but it’s not around the country. And, the big question is, “Is this much therapy appropriate?” (pause) Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
